description: Short form of pianoforte, from Italian pianoforte, from piano (“soft”) + forte (“strong”). So named because it could produce a wide range of varied volumes note-by-note, in contrast to older keyboard instruments, notably the harpsichord. Doublet of llano, plain, and plane.

entries.meaning: (music) a percussive keyboard musical instrument, usually ranging over seven octaves, with white and black colored keys, played by pressing these keys, causing hammers to strike strings [from  1803]
examples: The piano in his house takes up a lot of space.
She has been taking lessons for many years and now plays piano very well.
Coordinate terms: cembalo, clavichord, fortepiano, harpsichord, organ, synthesizer, synth

verbs.description: piano (third-person singular simple present pianos, present participle pianoing, simple past and past participle pianoed)

entries.meaning: (of or with fingers) To move (the fingers) up and down on, similar to the motions of a pianist playing the piano.

adjectives.description: piano (comparative more piano, superlative most piano)

examples: ‘Tradecraft, Chris,’ Enderby put in, who liked his bit of jargon, and Martindale, still piano, shot him a glance of admiration.

entries.meaning: (music) softly, as a musical direction (abbreviated to p. in sheet music) [from 17th c.]

verbs.description: piano (third-person singular simple present pianos, present participle pianoing, simple past and past participle pianoed)

entries.meaning: To become softer and less intense.
